House File 2438 - Introduced


                                 HOUSE FILE 

                                 HOUSE FILE 
                                 HOUSE FILE                                  HOUSE FILE                                  BY  COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND
                                     MEANS

                                 (SUCCESSOR TO HF 2288)
                                 (SUCCESSOR TO HSB 518)

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act relating to the administration of programs by the
  2    economic development authority by creating a renewable
  3    chemical production tax credit program, modifying the high
  4    quality jobs program,  and including effective date and other
  5    applicability provisions.
  6 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 5172HZ (1) 86
    mm/sc

PAG LIN



  1  1                           DIVISION I
  1  2                    HIGH QUALITY JOBS PROGRAM
  1  3    Section 1.  Section 15.119, subsection 2, paragraph a, Code
  1  4 2016, is amended to read as follows:
  1  5    a.                                       MEANS

  1 30        RENEWABLE CHEMICAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT PROGRAM
  1 31    Sec. 2.  Section 2.48, subsection 3, Code 2016, is amended by
  1 32 adding the following new paragraph:
  1 33      1 30        RENEWABLE CHEMICAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT PROGRAM
  1 31    Sec. 2.  Section 2.48, subsection 3, Code 2016, is amended by
  1 32 adding the following new paragraph:
  1 33      1 31    Sec. 2.  Section 2.48, subsection 3, Code 2016, is amended by
  1 32 adding the following new paragraph:
  1 33      1 32 adding the following new paragraph:
  1 33      1 33      1 34 production tax credit program available under sections 15.315
  1 35 through 15.322.
  2  1    Sec. 3.  Section 15.119, subsection 2, Code 2016, is amended
  2  2 by adding the following new paragraph:
  2  3      1 35 through 15.322.
  2  1    Sec. 3.  Section 15.119, subsection 2, Code 2016, is amended
  2  2 by adding the following new paragraph:
  2  3      2  1    Sec. 3.  Section 15.119, subsection 2, Code 2016, is amended
  2  2 by adding the following new paragraph:
  2  3      2  2 by adding the following new paragraph:
  2  3      2  3      2  4 credit program administered pursuant to sections 15.315 through
  2  5 15.322.  In allocating tax credits pursuant to this subsection,
  2  6 the authority shall not allocate more than ten million dollars
  2  7 for purposes of this paragraph. This paragraph is repealed
  2  8 July 1, 2030.
  2  9    Sec. 4.    2  5 15.322.  In allocating tax credits pursuant to this subsection,
  2  6 the authority shall not allocate more than ten million dollars
  2  7 for purposes of this paragraph. This paragraph is repealed
  2  8 July 1, 2030.
  2  9    Sec. 4.    2  6 the authority shall not allocate more than ten million dollars
  2  7 for purposes of this paragraph. This paragraph is repealed
  2  8 July 1, 2030.
  2  9    Sec. 4.    2  7 for purposes of this paragraph. This paragraph is repealed
  2  8 July 1, 2030.
  2  9    Sec. 4.    2  8 July 1, 2030.
  2  9    Sec. 4.    2  9    Sec. 4.    2 10    This part shall be known and may be cited as the "Renewable
  2 11 Chemical Production Tax Credit Program".
  2 12    Sec. 5.    2 11 Chemical Production Tax Credit Program".
  2 12    Sec. 5.    2 12    Sec. 5.    2 13    As used in this part, unless the context otherwise requires:
  2 14    1.  "Biobased content percentage" means, with respect to any
  2 15 renewable chemical, the amount, expressed as a percentage, of
  2 16 renewable organic material present as determined by testing
  2 17 representative samples using the American society for testing
  2 18 and materials standard D6866.
  2 19    2.  "Biomass feedstock" means sugar, polysaccharide, crude
  2 20 glycerin, lignin, fat, grease, or oil derived from a plant or
  2 21 animal, or a protein capable of being converted to a building
  2 22 block chemical by means of a biological or chemical conversion
  2 23 process.
  2 24    3.  "Building block chemical" means a molecule converted
  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily
  2 26 derived product that can be further refined into a higher=value
  2 27 chemical, material, or consumer product. "Building block
  2 28 chemical" includes but is not limited to high=purity glycerol,
  2 29 oleic acid, lauric acid, methanoic or formic acid, arabonic
  2 30 acid, erythonic acid, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, lactic
  2 31 acid, 3=hydroxypropionate, propionic acid, malonic acid,
  2 32 serine, succinic acid, fumaric acid, malic acid, aspartic
  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,
  3  2 sorbitol, gallic acid, ferulic acid, nonfuel butanol, nonfuel
  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the
  3  4 authority by rule after consultation with appropriate experts
  3  5 from Iowa state university, including but not limited to the
  3  6 Iowa state university center for biorenewable chemicals.
  3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    2 14    1.  "Biobased content percentage" means, with respect to any
  2 15 renewable chemical, the amount, expressed as a percentage, of
  2 16 renewable organic material present as determined by testing
  2 17 representative samples using the American society for testing
  2 18 and materials standard D6866.
  2 19    2.  "Biomass feedstock" means sugar, polysaccharide, crude
  2 20 glycerin, lignin, fat, grease, or oil derived from a plant or
  2 21 animal, or a protein capable of being converted to a building
  2 22 block chemical by means of a biological or chemical conversion
  2 23 process.
  2 24    3.  "Building block chemical" means a molecule converted
  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily
  2 26 derived product that can be further refined into a higher=value
  2 27 chemical, material, or consumer product. "Building block
  2 28 chemical" includes but is not limited to high=purity glycerol,
  2 29 oleic acid, lauric acid, methanoic or formic acid, arabonic
  2 30 acid, erythonic acid, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, lactic
  2 31 acid, 3=hydroxypropionate, propionic acid, malonic acid,
  2 32 serine, succinic acid, fumaric acid, malic acid, aspartic
  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,
  3  2 sorbitol, gallic acid, ferulic acid, nonfuel butanol, nonfuel
  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the
  3  4 authority by rule after consultation with appropriate experts
  3  5 from Iowa state university, including but not limited to the
  3  6 Iowa state university center for biorenewable chemicals.
  3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    2 15 renewable chemical, the amount, expressed as a percentage, of
  2 16 renewable organic material present as determined by testing
  2 17 representative samples using the American society for testing
  2 18 and materials standard D6866.
  2 19    2.  "Biomass feedstock" means sugar, polysaccharide, crude
  2 20 glycerin, lignin, fat, grease, or oil derived from a plant or
  2 21 animal, or a protein capable of being converted to a building
  2 22 block chemical by means of a biological or chemical conversion
  2 23 process.
  2 24    3.  "Building block chemical" means a molecule converted
  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily
  2 26 derived product that can be further refined into a higher=value
  2 27 chemical, material, or consumer product. "Building block
  2 28 chemical" includes but is not limited to high=purity glycerol,
  2 29 oleic acid, lauric acid, methanoic or formic acid, arabonic
  2 30 acid, erythonic acid, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, lactic
  2 31 acid, 3=hydroxypropionate, propionic acid, malonic acid,

  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,

  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the

  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    2 16 renewable organic material present as determined by testing
  2 17 representative samples using the American society for testing
  2 18 and materials standard D6866.
  2 19    2.  "Biomass feedstock" means sugar, polysaccharide, crude
  2 20 glycerin, lignin, fat, grease, or oil derived from a plant or
  2 21 animal, or a protein capable of being converted to a building
  2 22 block chemical by means of a biological or chemical conversion
  2 23 process.
  2 24    3.  "Building block chemical" means a molecule converted
  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily
  2 26 derived product that can be further refined into a higher=value
  2 27 chemical, material, or consumer product. "Building block
  2 28 chemical" includes but is not limited to high=purity glycerol,
  2 29 oleic acid, lauric acid, methanoic or formic acid, arabonic
  2 30 acid, erythonic acid, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, lactic
  2 31 acid, 3=hydroxypropionate, propionic acid, malonic acid,
  2 32 serine, succinic acid, fumaric acid, malic acid, aspartic
  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,
  3  2 sorbitol, gallic acid, ferulic acid, nonfuel butanol, nonfuel
  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the
  3  4 authority by rule after consultation with appropriate experts
  3  5 from Iowa state university, including but not limited to the
  3  6 Iowa state university center for biorenewable chemicals.
  3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.

  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are

  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily
  2 26 derived product that can be further refined into a higher=value
  2 27 chemical, material, or consumer product. "Building block
  2 28 chemical" includes but is not limited to high=purity glycerol,
  2 29 oleic acid, lauric acid, methanoic or formic acid, arabonic
  2 30 acid, erythonic acid, glyceric acid, glycolic acid, lactic
  2 31 acid, 3=hydroxypropionate, propionic acid, malonic acid,
  2 32 serine, succinic acid, fumaric acid, malic acid, aspartic
  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,
  3  2 sorbitol, gallic acid, ferulic acid, nonfuel butanol, nonfuel
  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the
  3  4 authority by rule after consultation with appropriate experts
  3  5 from Iowa state university, including but not limited to the
  3  6 Iowa state university center for biorenewable chemicals.
  3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    2 24    3.  "Building block chemical" means a molecule converted
  2 25 from biomass feedstock as a first product or a secondarily

  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.
  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    2 32 serine, succinic acid, fumaric acid, malic acid, aspartic
  2 33 acid, 3=hydroxybutyrolactone, acetoin, threonine, itaconic
  2 34 acid, furfural, levulinic acid, glutamic acid, xylonic acid,
  2 35 xylaric acid, xylitol, arabitol, citric acid, aconitic acid,
  3  1 5=hydroxymethylfurfural, lysine, gluconic acid, glucaric acid,
  3  2 sorbitol, gallic acid, ferulic acid, nonfuel butanol, nonfuel
  3  3 ethanol, or such additional molecules as may be included by the
  3  4 authority by rule after consultation with appropriate experts
  3  5 from Iowa state university, including but not limited to the
  3  6 Iowa state university center for biorenewable chemicals.
  3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.

  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    3  7    4.  "Crude glycerin" means glycerin with a purity level below
  3  8 ninety=five percent.
  3  9    5.  "Eligible business" means a business meeting the
  3 10 requirements of section 15.317.
  3 11    6.  "Food additive" means a building block chemical that
  3 12 is not primarily consumed as food but which, when combined
  3 13 with other components, improves the taste, appearance, odor,
  3 14 texture, or nutritional content of food.  The authority, in its
  3 15 discretion, shall determine whether or not a building block
  3 16 chemical is primarily consumed as food.
  3 17    7.  "High=purity glycerol" means glycerol with a purity level
  3 18 of ninety=five percent or higher.
  3 19    8.  "Pre=eligibility production threshold" means, with respect
  3 20 to each eligible business, the number of pounds of renewable
  3 21 chemicals produced, if any, by an eligible business during the
  3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.

  3 27    10.  "Renewable chemical" means a building block chemical
  3 28 with a biobased content percentage of at least fifty percent.
  3 29 "Renewable chemical" does not include a chemical sold or used
  3 30 for the production of food, feed, or fuel. "Renewable chemical"
  3 31 includes cellulosic ethanol, starch ethanol, or other ethanol
  3 32 derived from biomass feedstock, fatty acid methyl esters,
  3 33 or butanol, but only to the extent that such molecules are
  3 34 produced and sold for uses other than food, feed, or fuel.
  3 35 "Renewable chemical" also includes a building block chemical
  4  1 that can be a food additive as long as the building block
  4  2 chemical is not primarily consumed as food and is also sold
  4  3 for uses other than food.  "Renewable chemical" also includes
  4  4 supplements, vitamins, nutraceuticals, and pharmaceuticals, but
  4  5 only to the extent that such molecules do not provide caloric
  4  6 value so as to be considered sustenance as food or feed.
  4  7    11.  "Sugar" means the organic compound glucose, fructose,
  4  8 xylose, arabinose, lactose, sucrose, starch, cellulose, or
  4  9 hemicellulose.
  4 10    Sec. 6.    3 22 calendar year prior to the calendar year in which the business
  3 23 first qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section
  3 24 15.317.
  3 25    9.  "Program" means the renewable chemical production tax
  3 26 credit program administered pursuant to this part.

  4 10    Sec. 6.    4 10    Sec. 6.    4 11    To be eligible to receive the renewable chemical production
  4 12 tax credit pursuant to the program, a business shall meet all
  4 13 of the following requirements:
  4 14    1.  The business is physically located in this state.
  4 15    2.  The business is operated for profit and under single
  4 16 management.
  4 17    3.  The business is not an entity providing professional
  4 18 services, health care services, or medical treatments or an
  4 19 entity engaged primarily in retail operations.
  4 20    4.  The business organized, expanded, or located in the state
  4 21 on or after the effective date of this division of this Act.
  4 22    5.  The business shall not be relocating or reducing
  4 23 operations as described in section 15.329, subsection 1,
  4 24 paragraph "b", and as determined under the discretion of the
  4 25 authority.
  4 26    6.  The business is in compliance with all agreements entered
  4 27 into under this program or other programs administered by the
  4 28 authority.
  4 29    Sec. 7.    4 12 tax credit pursuant to the program, a business shall meet all
  4 13 of the following requirements:
  4 14    1.  The business is physically located in this state.

  4 16 management.

  4 27 into under this program or other programs administered by the
  4 28 authority.
  4 29    Sec. 7.    4 27 into under this program or other programs administered by the
  4 28 authority.
  4 29    Sec. 7.    4 28 authority.
  4 29    Sec. 7.    4 29    Sec. 7.    4 30 and agreement ==== maximum tax credits.
  4 31    1.  Application.
  4 32    a.  An eligible business that produces a renewable chemical
  4 33 in this state from biomass feedstock during a calendar year may
  4 34 apply to the authority for the renewable chemical production
  4 35 tax credit provided in section 15.319.
  5  1    b.  The application shall be made to the authority in the
  5  2 manner prescribed by the authority.
  5  3    c.  The application shall be made during the calendar year
  5  4 following the calendar year in which the renewable chemicals
  5  5 are produced.
  5  6    d.  The authority may accept applications on a continuous
  5  7 basis or may establish, by rule, an annual application
  5  8 deadline.
  5  9    e.  The application shall include all of the following
  5 10 information:
  5 11    (1)  The amount of renewable chemicals produced in the state
  5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    4 31    1.  Application.
  4 32    a.  An eligible business that produces a renewable chemical
  4 33 in this state from biomass feedstock during a calendar year may
  4 34 apply to the authority for the renewable chemical production
  4 35 tax credit provided in section 15.319.
  5  1    b.  The application shall be made to the authority in the
  5  2 manner prescribed by the authority.
  5  3    c.  The application shall be made during the calendar year
  5  4 following the calendar year in which the renewable chemicals
  5  5 are produced.
  5  6    d.  The authority may accept applications on a continuous
  5  7 basis or may establish, by rule, an annual application
  5  8 deadline.
  5  9    e.  The application shall include all of the following
  5 10 information:
  5 11    (1)  The amount of renewable chemicals produced in the state
  5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.

  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5  1    b.  The application shall be made to the authority in the
  5  2 manner prescribed by the authority.
  5  3    c.  The application shall be made during the calendar year
  5  4 following the calendar year in which the renewable chemicals
  5  5 are produced.
  5  6    d.  The authority may accept applications on a continuous
  5  7 basis or may establish, by rule, an annual application
  5  8 deadline.
  5  9    e.  The application shall include all of the following
  5 10 information:
  5 11    (1)  The amount of renewable chemicals produced in the state
  5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.

  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5  6    d.  The authority may accept applications on a continuous
  5  7 basis or may establish, by rule, an annual application
  5  8 deadline.
  5  9    e.  The application shall include all of the following
  5 10 information:
  5 11    (1)  The amount of renewable chemicals produced in the state
  5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5  7 basis or may establish, by rule, an annual application
  5  8 deadline.
  5  9    e.  The application shall include all of the following
  5 10 information:
  5 11    (1)  The amount of renewable chemicals produced in the state
  5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.

  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.

  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that

  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant

  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits

  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 12 from biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the
  5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.
  5 17    2.  Agreement and fees.
  5 18    a.  Before being issued a tax credit under section 15.319,
  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 13 calendar year, measured in pounds.
  5 14    (2)  Any other information reasonably required by the
  5 15 authority in order to establish and verify eligibility under
  5 16 the program.

  5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 19 an eligible business shall enter into an agreement with the
  5 20 authority for the successful completion of all requirements of
  5 21 the program.  As part of the agreement, the eligible business
  5 22 shall agree to collect and provide any information reasonably
  5 23 required by the authority in order to allow the board to
  5 24 fulfill its reporting obligation under section 15.320.
  5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.

  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 25    b.  The compliance cost fees authorized in section 15.330,
  5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 26 subsection 12, shall apply to all agreements entered into
  5 27 under this program and shall be collected by the authority in
  5 28 the same manner and to the same extent as described in that
  5 29 subsection.
  5 30    c.  An eligible business shall fulfill all the requirements
  5 31 of the program and the agreement before receiving a tax credit
  5 32 or entering into a subsequent agreement under this section.
  5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
