  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.

  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    5 33 The authority may decline to enter into a subsequent agreement
  5 34 under this section or issue a tax credit if an agreement is not
  5 35 successfully fulfilled.
  6  1    d.  Upon establishing that all requirements of the program
  6  2 and the agreement have been fulfilled, the authority shall
  6  3 issue a tax credit and related tax credit certificate to the
  6  4 eligible business stating the amount of renewable chemical
  6  5 production tax credit the eligible business may claim.
  6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.

  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information

  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by

  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    6  6    3.  Maximum tax credit amount.
  6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under
  6  8 section 15.319 to an eligible business for the production of
  6  9 renewable chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed the
  6 10 following:
  6 11    (1)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 12 operation in the state for five years or less at the time of
  6 13 application, one million dollars.
  6 14    (2)  In the case of an eligible business that has been in
  6 15 operation in the state for more than five years at the time of
  6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    6  7    a.  The maximum amount of tax credit that may be issued under

  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    6 16 application, five hundred thousand dollars.
  6 17    b.  An eligible business shall not receive a tax credit for
  6 18 renewable chemicals produced before the date the business first
  6 19 qualified as an eligible business pursuant to section 15.317.
  6 20    c.  An eligible business shall only receive a tax credit for
  6 21 renewable chemicals produced in a calendar year to the extent
  6 22 such production exceeds the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  6 23 production threshold.
  6 24    d.  An eligible business shall not receive more than five tax
  6 25 credits under the program.
  6 26    e.  The authority shall issue tax credits under the program
  6 27 on a first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
  6 28 tax credits allocated pursuant to section 15.119, subsection
  6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.

  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.
  7 16    5.  Confidentiality.
  7 17    a.  Except as provided in paragraph "b", any information
  7 18 or record in the possession of the authority with respect to
  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    6 29 2, paragraph "h", is reached.  The authority shall maintain
  6 30 a list of successful applicants under the program, so that
  6 31 if the maximum aggregate amount of tax credits is reached in
  6 32 a given fiscal year, eligible businesses that successfully
  6 33 applied but for which tax credits were not issued shall be
  6 34 placed on a wait list in the order the eligible businesses
  6 35 applied and shall be given priority for receiving tax credits
  7  1 in succeeding fiscal years. Placement on a wait list pursuant
  7  2 to this paragraph shall not constitute a promise binding the
  7  3 state. The availability of a tax credit and issuance of a tax
  7  4 credit certificate pursuant to this subsection in a future
  7  5 fiscal year is contingent upon the availability of tax credits
  7  6 in that particular fiscal year.
  7  7    4.  Termination and repayment.  The failure by an eligible
  7  8 business in fulfilling any requirement of the program or any of
  7  9 the terms and obligations of an agreement entered into pursuant
  7 10 to this section may result in the reduction, termination,
  7 11 or recision of the tax credits under section 15.319 and may
  7 12 subject the eligible business to the repayment or recapture of
  7 13 tax credits claimed.  The repayment or recapture of tax credits
  7 14 pursuant to this subsection shall be accomplished in the same
  7 15 manner as provided in section 15.330, subsection 2.

  7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 19 the program shall be presumed by the authority to be a trade
  7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 20 secret protected under chapter 550 or common law and shall be
  7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 21 kept confidential by the authority unless otherwise ordered by
  7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 22 a court.
  7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 23    b.  The identity of a tax credit recipient and the amount
  7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 24 of the tax credit shall be considered public information under
  7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 25 chapter 22.
  7 26    Sec. 8.    7 26    Sec. 8.    7 27 tax credit.
  7 28    1.  An eligible business that has entered into an agreement
  7 29 pursuant to section 15.318 may claim a tax credit in an amount
  7 30 equal to the product of five cents multiplied by the number
  7 31 of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in this state from
  7 32 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
  7 33 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  7 34 production threshold. However, an eligible business shall
  7 35 not receive a tax credit for the production of a secondarily
  8  1 derived building block chemical if that chemical is also the
  8  2 subject of a credit at the time of production as a first
  8  3 product. The renewable chemical production tax credit shall
  8  4 not be available for any renewable chemical produced before the
  8  5 2017 calendar year or after the 2026 calendar year.
  8  6    2.  The tax credit shall be allowed against taxes imposed
  8  7 under chapter 422, division II or III.
  8  8    3.  The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during
  8  9 which the eligible business was issued the tax credit.
  8 10    4.  An individual may claim a tax credit under this section
  8 11 of a partnership, limited liability company, S corporation,
  8 12 cooperative organized under chapter 501 and filing as a
  8 13 partnership for federal tax purposes, estate, or trust electing
  8 14 to have income taxed directly to the individual. The amount
  8 15 claimed by the individual shall be based upon the pro rata
  8 16 share of the individual's earnings from the partnership,
  8 17 limited liability company, S corporation, cooperative, estate,
  8 18 or trust.
  8 19    5.  Any tax credit in excess of the tax liability is
  8 20 refundable.  In lieu of claiming a refund, the taxpayer
  8 21 may elect to have the overpayment shown on the taxpayer's
  8 22 final, completed return credited to the tax liability for the
  8 23 following tax year.
  8 24    6.  a.  To claim a tax credit under this section, a taxpayer
  8 25 shall include one or more tax credit certificates with the
  8 26 taxpayer's tax return.
  8 27    b.  The tax credit certificate shall contain the taxpayer's
  8 28 name, address, tax identification number, the amount of the
  8 29 credit, the name of the eligible business, and any other
  8 30 information required by the department of revenue.
  8 31    c.  The tax credit certificate, unless rescinded by the
  8 32 authority, shall be accepted by the department of revenue as
  8 33 payment for taxes imposed pursuant to chapter 422, divisions II
  8 34 and III, subject to any conditions or restrictions placed by
  8 35 the authority upon the face of the tax credit certificate and
  9  1 subject to the limitations of the program.
  9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    7 28    1.  An eligible business that has entered into an agreement
  7 29 pursuant to section 15.318 may claim a tax credit in an amount
  7 30 equal to the product of five cents multiplied by the number
  7 31 of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in this state from
  7 32 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
  7 33 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
  7 34 production threshold. However, an eligible business shall
  7 35 not receive a tax credit for the production of a secondarily
  8  1 derived building block chemical if that chemical is also the
  8  2 subject of a credit at the time of production as a first
  8  3 product. The renewable chemical production tax credit shall
  8  4 not be available for any renewable chemical produced before the
  8  5 2017 calendar year or after the 2026 calendar year.
  8  6    2.  The tax credit shall be allowed against taxes imposed
  8  7 under chapter 422, division II or III.
  8  8    3.  The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during
  8  9 which the eligible business was issued the tax credit.
  8 10    4.  An individual may claim a tax credit under this section
  8 11 of a partnership, limited liability company, S corporation,
  8 12 cooperative organized under chapter 501 and filing as a
  8 13 partnership for federal tax purposes, estate, or trust electing
  8 14 to have income taxed directly to the individual. The amount
  8 15 claimed by the individual shall be based upon the pro rata
  8 16 share of the individual's earnings from the partnership,
  8 17 limited liability company, S corporation, cooperative, estate,
  8 18 or trust.
  8 19    5.  Any tax credit in excess of the tax liability is
  8 20 refundable.  In lieu of claiming a refund, the taxpayer
  8 21 may elect to have the overpayment shown on the taxpayer's
  8 22 final, completed return credited to the tax liability for the
  8 23 following tax year.
  8 24    6.  a.  To claim a tax credit under this section, a taxpayer
  8 25 shall include one or more tax credit certificates with the
  8 26 taxpayer's tax return.

  8 28 name, address, tax identification number, the amount of the
  8 29 credit, the name of the eligible business, and any other
  8 30 information required by the department of revenue.
  8 31    c.  The tax credit certificate, unless rescinded by the
  8 32 authority, shall be accepted by the department of revenue as
  8 33 payment for taxes imposed pursuant to chapter 422, divisions II
  8 34 and III, subject to any conditions or restrictions placed by
  8 35 the authority upon the face of the tax credit certificate and
  9  1 subject to the limitations of the program.
  9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.

  8  6    2.  The tax credit shall be allowed against taxes imposed
  8  7 under chapter 422, division II or III.
  8  8    3.  The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during
  8  9 which the eligible business was issued the tax credit.
  8 10    4.  An individual may claim a tax credit under this section
  8 11 of a partnership, limited liability company, S corporation,
  8 12 cooperative organized under chapter 501 and filing as a
  8 13 partnership for federal tax purposes, estate, or trust electing
  8 14 to have income taxed directly to the individual. The amount
  8 15 claimed by the individual shall be based upon the pro rata
  8 16 share of the individual's earnings from the partnership,
  8 17 limited liability company, S corporation, cooperative, estate,
  8 18 or trust.
  8 19    5.  Any tax credit in excess of the tax liability is
  8 20 refundable.  In lieu of claiming a refund, the taxpayer
  8 21 may elect to have the overpayment shown on the taxpayer's
  8 22 final, completed return credited to the tax liability for the
  8 23 following tax year.
  8 24    6.  a.  To claim a tax credit under this section, a taxpayer
  8 25 shall include one or more tax credit certificates with the
  8 26 taxpayer's tax return.
  8 27    b.  The tax credit certificate shall contain the taxpayer's
  8 28 name, address, tax identification number, the amount of the
  8 29 credit, the name of the eligible business, and any other
  8 30 information required by the department of revenue.
  8 31    c.  The tax credit certificate, unless rescinded by the
  8 32 authority, shall be accepted by the department of revenue as
  8 33 payment for taxes imposed pursuant to chapter 422, divisions II
  8 34 and III, subject to any conditions or restrictions placed by
  8 35 the authority upon the face of the tax credit certificate and
  9  1 subject to the limitations of the program.
  9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    8  4 not be available for any renewable chemical produced before the
  8  5 2017 calendar year or after the 2026 calendar year.
  8  6    2.  The tax credit shall be allowed against taxes imposed
  8  7 under chapter 422, division II or III.
  8  8    3.  The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during

  8 32 authority, shall be accepted by the department of revenue as
  8 33 payment for taxes imposed pursuant to chapter 422, divisions II
  8 34 and III, subject to any conditions or restrictions placed by
  8 35 the authority upon the face of the tax credit certificate and
  9  1 subject to the limitations of the program.
  9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    8 22 final, completed return credited to the tax liability for the
  8 23 following tax year.
  8 24    6.  a.  To claim a tax credit under this section, a taxpayer
  8 25 shall include one or more tax credit certificates with the
  8 26 taxpayer's tax return.
  8 27    b.  The tax credit certificate shall contain the taxpayer's
  8 28 name, address, tax identification number, the amount of the
  8 29 credit, the name of the eligible business, and any other
  8 30 information required by the department of revenue.
  8 31    c.  The tax credit certificate, unless rescinded by the
  8 32 authority, shall be accepted by the department of revenue as
  8 33 payment for taxes imposed pursuant to chapter 422, divisions II
  8 34 and III, subject to any conditions or restrictions placed by
  8 35 the authority upon the face of the tax credit certificate and
  9  1 subject to the limitations of the program.
  9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    8 23 following tax year.
  8 24    6.  a.  To claim a tax credit under this section, a taxpayer
  8 25 shall include one or more tax credit certificates with the
  8 26 taxpayer's tax return.

  9  4    Sec. 9.    9  2    d.  Tax credit certificates issued pursuant to this section
  9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    9  3 shall not be transferred to any other person.
  9  4    Sec. 9.    9  4    Sec. 9.    9  5    1.  For purposes of this section, "successful tax credit
  9  6 applicant" includes, with respect to each calendar year, an
  9  7 eligible business that was issued a tax credit for production
  9  8 of renewable chemicals during that calendar year, and an
  9  9 eligible business that successfully applied for a tax credit
  9 10 for the production of renewable chemicals during that calendar
  9 11 year, but was not issued a tax credit and was instead placed on
  9 12 a wait list pursuant to section 15.318, subsection 3, paragraph
  9 13 "e".
  9 14    2. By January 31, 2019, and by the same date each year
  9 15 thereafter, the board, in cooperation with the department of
  9 16 revenue, shall submit to the general assembly and the governor
  9 17 a report describing the activities of the program for the most
  9 18 recent calendar year for which the tax credit application
  9 19 period has ended pursuant to section 15.318, subsection 1,
  9 20 paragraph "c".  The report shall at a minimum include the
  9 21 following information:
  9 22    a.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each type,
  9 23 of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa by all successful
  9 24 tax credit applicants during the calendar year prior to the
  9 25 calendar year for which the successful applicants first applied
  9 26 for a tax credit under the program.
  9 27    b.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each type,
  9 28 of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa by all successful tax
  9 29 credit applicants during each calendar year.
  9 30    c.  The aggregate sales of all renewable chemicals produced
  9 31 by all successful tax credit applicants in each calendar
  9 32 year for which there are at least five successful tax credit
  9 33 applicants.
  9 34    d.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each
  9 35 type, of biomass feedstock used in the production of renewable
 10  1 chemicals in Iowa by all successful tax credit applicants
 10  2 during the calendar year prior to the calendar year for which
 10  3 the successful applicants first applied for a tax credit under
 10  4 the program.
 10  5    e.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each
 10  6 type, of biomass feedstock used in the production of renewable
 10  7 chemicals in Iowa by all successful tax credit applicants
 10  8 during each calendar year.
 10  9    f.  The number of employees located in Iowa of all successful
 10 10 tax credit applicants during the calendar year prior to the
 10 11 calendar year for which the successful applicants first applied
 10 12 for a tax credit under the program.
 10 13    g.  The number of employees located in Iowa of all successful
 10 14 tax credit applicants during each calendar year.
 10 15    h.  The number and aggregate amount of tax credits issued
 10 16 under the program for each calendar year.
 10 17    i.  The number of eligible businesses placed on the wait
 10 18 list for each calendar year, and the total number of eligible
 10 19 businesses remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 20 calendar year.
 10 21    j.  The dollar amount of tax credit claims placed on the wait
 10 22 list for each calendar year, and the total dollar amount of tax
 10 23 credit claims remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 24 calendar year.
 10 25    3.  To protect the presumption of confidentiality
 10 26 established in section 15.318, subsection 5, the board shall
 10 27 report all information in an aggregate form to prevent, as much
 10 28 as possible, information being attributable to any particular
 10 29 eligible business.

  9 24 tax credit applicants during the calendar year prior to the
  9 25 calendar year for which the successful applicants first applied
  9 26 for a tax credit under the program.
  9 27    b.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each type,
  9 28 of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa by all successful tax
  9 29 credit applicants during each calendar year.
  9 30    c.  The aggregate sales of all renewable chemicals produced
  9 31 by all successful tax credit applicants in each calendar
  9 32 year for which there are at least five successful tax credit
  9 33 applicants.
  9 34    d.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each
  9 35 type, of biomass feedstock used in the production of renewable
 10  1 chemicals in Iowa by all successful tax credit applicants
 10  2 during the calendar year prior to the calendar year for which
 10  3 the successful applicants first applied for a tax credit under
 10  4 the program.
 10  5    e.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each
 10  6 type, of biomass feedstock used in the production of renewable
 10  7 chemicals in Iowa by all successful tax credit applicants
 10  8 during each calendar year.
 10  9    f.  The number of employees located in Iowa of all successful
 10 10 tax credit applicants during the calendar year prior to the
 10 11 calendar year for which the successful applicants first applied
 10 12 for a tax credit under the program.
 10 13    g.  The number of employees located in Iowa of all successful
 10 14 tax credit applicants during each calendar year.
 10 15    h.  The number and aggregate amount of tax credits issued
 10 16 under the program for each calendar year.
 10 17    i.  The number of eligible businesses placed on the wait
 10 18 list for each calendar year, and the total number of eligible
 10 19 businesses remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 20 calendar year.
 10 21    j.  The dollar amount of tax credit claims placed on the wait
 10 22 list for each calendar year, and the total dollar amount of tax
 10 23 credit claims remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 24 calendar year.

 10 26 established in section 15.318, subsection 5, the board shall
 10 27 report all information in an aggregate form to prevent, as much
 10 28 as possible, information being attributable to any particular
 10 29 eligible business.

 10 14 tax credit applicants during each calendar year.

 10 22 list for each calendar year, and the total dollar amount of tax
 10 23 credit claims remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 24 calendar year.

 10 21    j.  The dollar amount of tax credit claims placed on the wait
 10 22 list for each calendar year, and the total dollar amount of tax
 10 23 credit claims remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 24 calendar year.
 10 25    3.  To protect the presumption of confidentiality
 10 26 established in section 15.318, subsection 5, the board shall
 10 27 report all information in an aggregate form to prevent, as much
 10 28 as possible, information being attributable to any particular
 10 29 eligible business.
 10 30    Sec. 10.   10  4 the program.
 10  5    e.  The aggregate number of pounds, and a list of each
 10  6 type, of biomass feedstock used in the production of renewable
 10  7 chemicals in Iowa by all successful tax credit applicants
 10  8 during each calendar year.
 10  9    f.  The number of employees located in Iowa of all successful
 10 10 tax credit applicants during the calendar year prior to the
 10 11 calendar year for which the successful applicants first applied
 10 12 for a tax credit under the program.

 10 14 tax credit applicants during each calendar year.

 10 16 under the program for each calendar year.

 10 18 list for each calendar year, and the total number of eligible
 10 19 businesses remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 20 calendar year.

 10 22 list for each calendar year, and the total dollar amount of tax
 10 23 credit claims remaining on the wait list at the end of that
 10 24 calendar year.

 11  6 chemical production tax credit allowed under section 15.319.

 11 13 January 1, 2033.
 11 14    Sec. 14.  TAX CREDIT CLAIMS.  Renewable chemical production
 11 15 tax credits issued pursuant to the renewable chemical
 11 16 production tax credit program enacted in this division of this
 11 17 Act shall not be issued by the economic development authority
 11 18 prior to July 1, 2018, and shall not be claimed by a taxpayer
 11 19 prior to September 1, 2018.
 11 20    Sec. 15.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This division of this
 11 21 Act, being deemed of immediate importance, takes effect upon
 11 22 enactment.
 11 23    Sec. 16.  APPLICABILITY.  This division of this Act applies
 11 24 to renewable chemicals produced in the state from biomass
 11 25 feedstock on or after January 1, 2017.
 11 26                           EXPLANATION
 11 27 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 11 28 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 11 29    This bill relates to the administration of programs by
 11 30 the economic development authority (EDA) by modifying the
 11 31 high quality jobs program and creating a renewable chemical
 11 32 production tax credit program.
 11 33    DIVISION I ==== HIGH QUALITY JOBS PROGRAM.  Division I limits
 11 34 for a period of five or six fiscal years the amount of tax
 11 35 credits that may be allocated to the high quality jobs program,
 12  1 which under current law is subject to EDA's maximum aggregate
 12  2 tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal year in Code section
 12  3 15.119.  The bill provides that for each of the five fiscal
 12  4 years beginning on July 1, 2016, and ending on June 30, 2021,
 12  5 the authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of
 12  6 that $170 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This
 12  7 provision is repealed July 1, 2021.
 12  8    If the aggregate amount of renewable chemical production
 12  9 tax credits awarded by EDA for the fiscal period beginning on
 12 10 July 1, 2018, and ending June 30, 2021, equals or exceeds $27
 12 11 million, then an additional year of high quality jobs program
 12 12 tax credit allocation limitation occurs and for the fiscal
 12 13 year beginning July 1, 2021, and ending June 30, 2022, the
 12 14 authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of its $170
 12 15 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This provision
 12 16 is repealed July 1, 2022.
 12 17    DIVISION II ==== RENEWABLE CHEMICAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT.
 12 18   Division II creates a renewable chemical production tax credit
 12 19 program (program) that will be administered by the EDA and that
 12 20 will provide tax credits to eligible businesses that produce
 12 21 renewable chemicals in Iowa from biomass feedstock.  "Renewable
 12 22 chemical", "biomass feedstock", and other related terms are
 12 23 defined in the division.
 12 24    In order to qualify for the tax credit, a business must
 12 25 meet several requirements.  First, the business must be
 12 26 physically located in Iowa and operated for profit under
 12 27 single management.  Second, the business must not be an
 12 28 entity providing professional services, health care services,
 12 29 or medical treatments, or be engaged primarily in retail
 12 30 operations.  Third, the business must have organized, expanded,
 12 31 or located in Iowa on or after the effective date of the
 12 32 division.  Fourth, the business must not be, in the discretion
 12 33 of the EDA, ineligible under certain provisions relating to the
 12 34 relocation or reduction of business operations within Iowa.
 12 35 Fifth, the business must be in compliance with all agreements
 13  1 entered into under the program or other programs administered
 13  2 by the EDA.
 13  3    An eligible business seeking a tax credit is required to
 13  4 submit an application to the EDA containing various information
 13  5 during the calendar year following the calendar year in which
 13  6 the renewable chemicals are produced. The EDA may accept
 13  7 applications on a continuous basis or may establish an annual
 13  8 application deadline.
 13  9    Before being issued a tax credit, an eligible business
 13 10 is required to enter into an agreement with the EDA for the
 13 11 successful completion of all requirements of the program.  The
 13 12 EDA is authorized to impose two compliance cost fees under the
 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second
 13 14 fee equals 0.5 percent of the value of the tax credit claimed
 13 15 pursuant to the agreement if the agreement has an aggregate tax
 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.
 13 17    An eligible business that fails to comply with the
 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
 13 32    The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during which
 13 33 the eligible business was issued the tax credit.  However, tax
 13 34 credits shall not be issued by EDA prior to July 1, 2018, or
 13 35 claimed by the taxpayer prior to September 1, 2018. The tax
 14  1 credit may be claimed against the individual income tax and the
 14  2 corporate income tax.  The credit is refundable or may, at the
 14  3 election of the taxpayer, be carried forward for up to one tax
 14  4 year.   The tax credit shall not be transferred to any person.
 14  5    The division provides that the program is subject to EDA's
 14  6 maximum aggregate tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal
 14  7 year in Code section 15.119, and not more than $10 million
 14  8 per fiscal year may be issued by the EDA under the program.
 14  9 In addition, the maximum amount of tax credit that may be
 14 10 issued to an eligible business for the production of renewable
 14 11 chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed $1 million or
 14 12 $500,000, depending on whether the eligible business has been
 14 13 operating in Iowa at the time of application for five or fewer
 14 14 years, or more than five years, respectively.  An eligible
 14 15 business shall not receive more than five tax credits under
 14 16 the program.  The EDA is required to issue tax credits on a
 14 17 first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
 14 18 $10 million per fiscal year is reached.  If the amount of
 14 19 tax credits exceeds this amount in a fiscal year, the EDA
 14 20 is required to establish a wait list and give priority in
 14 21 subsequent years to the eligible businesses on the wait list.
 14 22    The division provides for the confidentiality of certain
 14 23 information under the program.  The identity of a tax credit
 14 24 recipient and the amount of the tax credit shall be considered
 14 25 public information under Code chapter 22 (examination of public
 14 26 records), but any other information or record in the possession
 14 27 of the EDA with respect to the program shall be presumed by
 14 28 the EDA to be a trade secret protected under Code chapter 550
 14 29 or common law and shall be kept confidential by the EDA unless
 14 30 otherwise ordered by a court.
 14 31    The division requires EDA to submit to the general assembly
 14 32 and the governor an annual report describing the activities of
 14 33 the program for each calendar year and including information
 14 34 specified in the division. Information is required to be
 14 35 reported in an aggregate form to protect the presumption
 15  1 of confidentiality and to prevent, as much as possible,
 15  2 information being attributable to any particular eligible
 15  3 business.  The report for the first calendar year the tax
 15  4 credit is available under the program (2017) is due by January
 15  5 31, 2019, and reports covering subsequent calendar years are
 15  6 due by the same date each year thereafter.  Eligible businesses
 15  7 are required, as part of their agreement with EDA, to collect
 15  8 and provide any information reasonably required by EDA in order
 15  9 to fulfill this reporting requirement.
 15 10    The division adds the program to the list of tax expenditures
 15 11 to be reviewed by the legislative tax expenditure committee in
 15 12 calendar year 2022.
 15 13    The tax credit program is repealed July 1, 2030. References
 15 14 to the renewable chemical production tax credit in provisions
 15 15 of the Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax
 15 16 are repealed January 1, 2033.
 15 17    The division takes effect upon enactment and applies to
 15 18 renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from biomass feedstock on
 15 19 or after January 1, 2017.
       LSB 5172HZ (1) 86
       mm/sc
 11 12 allowed under section 15.319. This subsection is repealed
 11 13 January 1, 2033.
 11 14    Sec. 14.  TAX CREDIT CLAIMS.  Renewable chemical production
 11 15 tax credits issued pursuant to the renewable chemical
 11 16 production tax credit program enacted in this division of this
 11 17 Act shall not be issued by the economic development authority
 11 18 prior to July 1, 2018, and shall not be claimed by a taxpayer
 11 19 prior to September 1, 2018.
 11 20    Sec. 15.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This division of this
 11 21 Act, being deemed of immediate importance, takes effect upon
 11 22 enactment.
 11 23    Sec. 16.  APPLICABILITY.  This division of this Act applies
 11 24 to renewable chemicals produced in the state from biomass
 11 25 feedstock on or after January 1, 2017.
 11 26                           EXPLANATION
 11 27 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 11 28 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 11 29    This bill relates to the administration of programs by
 11 30 the economic development authority (EDA) by modifying the
 11 31 high quality jobs program and creating a renewable chemical
 11 32 production tax credit program.
 11 33    DIVISION I ==== HIGH QUALITY JOBS PROGRAM.  Division I limits
 11 34 for a period of five or six fiscal years the amount of tax
 11 35 credits that may be allocated to the high quality jobs program,
 12  1 which under current law is subject to EDA's maximum aggregate
 12  2 tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal year in Code section
 12  3 15.119.  The bill provides that for each of the five fiscal
 12  4 years beginning on July 1, 2016, and ending on June 30, 2021,
 12  5 the authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of
 12  6 that $170 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This
 12  7 provision is repealed July 1, 2021.
 12  8    If the aggregate amount of renewable chemical production
 12  9 tax credits awarded by EDA for the fiscal period beginning on
 12 10 July 1, 2018, and ending June 30, 2021, equals or exceeds $27
 12 11 million, then an additional year of high quality jobs program
 12 12 tax credit allocation limitation occurs and for the fiscal
 12 13 year beginning July 1, 2021, and ending June 30, 2022, the
 12 14 authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of its $170
 12 15 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This provision
 12 16 is repealed July 1, 2022.
 12 17    DIVISION II ==== RENEWABLE CHEMICAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT.
 12 18   Division II creates a renewable chemical production tax credit
 12 19 program (program) that will be administered by the EDA and that
 12 20 will provide tax credits to eligible businesses that produce
 12 21 renewable chemicals in Iowa from biomass feedstock.  "Renewable
 12 22 chemical", "biomass feedstock", and other related terms are
 12 23 defined in the division.
 12 24    In order to qualify for the tax credit, a business must
 12 25 meet several requirements.  First, the business must be
 12 26 physically located in Iowa and operated for profit under
 12 27 single management.  Second, the business must not be an
 12 28 entity providing professional services, health care services,
 12 29 or medical treatments, or be engaged primarily in retail
 12 30 operations.  Third, the business must have organized, expanded,
 12 31 or located in Iowa on or after the effective date of the
 12 32 division.  Fourth, the business must not be, in the discretion
 12 33 of the EDA, ineligible under certain provisions relating to the
 12 34 relocation or reduction of business operations within Iowa.
 12 35 Fifth, the business must be in compliance with all agreements
 13  1 entered into under the program or other programs administered
 13  2 by the EDA.
 13  3    An eligible business seeking a tax credit is required to
 13  4 submit an application to the EDA containing various information
 13  5 during the calendar year following the calendar year in which
 13  6 the renewable chemicals are produced. The EDA may accept
 13  7 applications on a continuous basis or may establish an annual
 13  8 application deadline.
 13  9    Before being issued a tax credit, an eligible business
 13 10 is required to enter into an agreement with the EDA for the
 13 11 successful completion of all requirements of the program.  The
 13 12 EDA is authorized to impose two compliance cost fees under the
 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second
 13 14 fee equals 0.5 percent of the value of the tax credit claimed
 13 15 pursuant to the agreement if the agreement has an aggregate tax
 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.
 13 17    An eligible business that fails to comply with the
 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
 13 32    The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during which
 13 33 the eligible business was issued the tax credit.  However, tax
 13 34 credits shall not be issued by EDA prior to July 1, 2018, or
 13 35 claimed by the taxpayer prior to September 1, 2018. The tax
 14  1 credit may be claimed against the individual income tax and the
 14  2 corporate income tax.  The credit is refundable or may, at the
 14  3 election of the taxpayer, be carried forward for up to one tax
 14  4 year.   The tax credit shall not be transferred to any person.
 14  5    The division provides that the program is subject to EDA's
 14  6 maximum aggregate tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal
 14  7 year in Code section 15.119, and not more than $10 million
 14  8 per fiscal year may be issued by the EDA under the program.
 14  9 In addition, the maximum amount of tax credit that may be
 14 10 issued to an eligible business for the production of renewable
 14 11 chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed $1 million or
 14 12 $500,000, depending on whether the eligible business has been
 14 13 operating in Iowa at the time of application for five or fewer
 14 14 years, or more than five years, respectively.  An eligible
 14 15 business shall not receive more than five tax credits under
 14 16 the program.  The EDA is required to issue tax credits on a
 14 17 first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
 14 18 $10 million per fiscal year is reached.  If the amount of
 14 19 tax credits exceeds this amount in a fiscal year, the EDA
 14 20 is required to establish a wait list and give priority in
 14 21 subsequent years to the eligible businesses on the wait list.
 14 22    The division provides for the confidentiality of certain
 14 23 information under the program.  The identity of a tax credit
 14 24 recipient and the amount of the tax credit shall be considered
 14 25 public information under Code chapter 22 (examination of public
 14 26 records), but any other information or record in the possession
 14 27 of the EDA with respect to the program shall be presumed by
 14 28 the EDA to be a trade secret protected under Code chapter 550
 14 29 or common law and shall be kept confidential by the EDA unless
 14 30 otherwise ordered by a court.
 14 31    The division requires EDA to submit to the general assembly
 14 32 and the governor an annual report describing the activities of
 14 33 the program for each calendar year and including information
 14 34 specified in the division. Information is required to be
 14 35 reported in an aggregate form to protect the presumption
 15  1 of confidentiality and to prevent, as much as possible,
 15  2 information being attributable to any particular eligible
 15  3 business.  The report for the first calendar year the tax
 15  4 credit is available under the program (2017) is due by January
 15  5 31, 2019, and reports covering subsequent calendar years are
 15  6 due by the same date each year thereafter.  Eligible businesses
 15  7 are required, as part of their agreement with EDA, to collect
 15  8 and provide any information reasonably required by EDA in order
 15  9 to fulfill this reporting requirement.
 15 10    The division adds the program to the list of tax expenditures
 15 11 to be reviewed by the legislative tax expenditure committee in
 15 12 calendar year 2022.
 15 13    The tax credit program is repealed July 1, 2030. References
 15 14 to the renewable chemical production tax credit in provisions
 15 15 of the Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax
 15 16 are repealed January 1, 2033.
 15 17    The division takes effect upon enactment and applies to
 15 18 renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from biomass feedstock on
 15 19 or after January 1, 2017.
       LSB 5172HZ (1) 86
       mm/sc
 11 13 January 1, 2033.
 11 14    Sec. 14.  TAX CREDIT CLAIMS.  Renewable chemical production
 11 15 tax credits issued pursuant to the renewable chemical
 11 16 production tax credit program enacted in this division of this
 11 17 Act shall not be issued by the economic development authority
 11 18 prior to July 1, 2018, and shall not be claimed by a taxpayer
 11 19 prior to September 1, 2018.
 11 20    Sec. 15.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This division of this
 11 21 Act, being deemed of immediate importance, takes effect upon
 11 22 enactment.
 11 23    Sec. 16.  APPLICABILITY.  This division of this Act applies
 11 24 to renewable chemicals produced in the state from biomass
 11 25 feedstock on or after January 1, 2017.
 11 26                           EXPLANATION
 11 27 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 11 28 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 11 29    This bill relates to the administration of programs by
 11 30 the economic development authority (EDA) by modifying the
 11 31 high quality jobs program and creating a renewable chemical
 11 32 production tax credit program.

 11 35 credits that may be allocated to the high quality jobs program,

 12  2 tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal year in Code section
 12  3 15.119.  The bill provides that for each of the five fiscal
 12  4 years beginning on July 1, 2016, and ending on June 30, 2021,
 12  5 the authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of
 12  6 that $170 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This
 12  7 provision is repealed July 1, 2021.
 12  8    If the aggregate amount of renewable chemical production
 12  9 tax credits awarded by EDA for the fiscal period beginning on
 12 10 July 1, 2018, and ending June 30, 2021, equals or exceeds $27
 12 11 million, then an additional year of high quality jobs program
 12 12 tax credit allocation limitation occurs and for the fiscal
 12 13 year beginning July 1, 2021, and ending June 30, 2022, the
 12 14 authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of its $170
 12 15 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This provision
 12 16 is repealed July 1, 2022.

 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second
 13 14 fee equals 0.5 percent of the value of the tax credit claimed
 13 15 pursuant to the agreement if the agreement has an aggregate tax
 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.

 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
 13 32    The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during which
 13 33 the eligible business was issued the tax credit.  However, tax
 13 34 credits shall not be issued by EDA prior to July 1, 2018, or
 13 35 claimed by the taxpayer prior to September 1, 2018. The tax
 14  1 credit may be claimed against the individual income tax and the
 14  2 corporate income tax.  The credit is refundable or may, at the
 14  3 election of the taxpayer, be carried forward for up to one tax
 14  4 year.   The tax credit shall not be transferred to any person.
 14  5    The division provides that the program is subject to EDA's
 14  6 maximum aggregate tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal
 14  7 year in Code section 15.119, and not more than $10 million
 14  8 per fiscal year may be issued by the EDA under the program.
 14  9 In addition, the maximum amount of tax credit that may be
 14 10 issued to an eligible business for the production of renewable
 14 11 chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed $1 million or
 14 12 $500,000, depending on whether the eligible business has been
 14 13 operating in Iowa at the time of application for five or fewer
 14 14 years, or more than five years, respectively.  An eligible
 14 15 business shall not receive more than five tax credits under
 14 16 the program.  The EDA is required to issue tax credits on a
 14 17 first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
 14 18 $10 million per fiscal year is reached.  If the amount of
 14 19 tax credits exceeds this amount in a fiscal year, the EDA
 14 20 is required to establish a wait list and give priority in
 14 21 subsequent years to the eligible businesses on the wait list.
 14 22    The division provides for the confidentiality of certain
 14 23 information under the program.  The identity of a tax credit
 14 24 recipient and the amount of the tax credit shall be considered
 14 25 public information under Code chapter 22 (examination of public
 14 26 records), but any other information or record in the possession
 14 27 of the EDA with respect to the program shall be presumed by
 14 28 the EDA to be a trade secret protected under Code chapter 550
 14 29 or common law and shall be kept confidential by the EDA unless
 14 30 otherwise ordered by a court.
 14 31    The division requires EDA to submit to the general assembly
 14 32 and the governor an annual report describing the activities of
 14 33 the program for each calendar year and including information
 14 34 specified in the division. Information is required to be
 14 35 reported in an aggregate form to protect the presumption
 15  1 of confidentiality and to prevent, as much as possible,
 15  2 information being attributable to any particular eligible
 15  3 business.  The report for the first calendar year the tax
 15  4 credit is available under the program (2017) is due by January
 15  5 31, 2019, and reports covering subsequent calendar years are
 15  6 due by the same date each year thereafter.  Eligible businesses
 15  7 are required, as part of their agreement with EDA, to collect
 15  8 and provide any information reasonably required by EDA in order
 15  9 to fulfill this reporting requirement.
 15 10    The division adds the program to the list of tax expenditures
 15 11 to be reviewed by the legislative tax expenditure committee in
 15 12 calendar year 2022.
 15 13    The tax credit program is repealed July 1, 2030. References
 15 14 to the renewable chemical production tax credit in provisions
 15 15 of the Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax
 15 16 are repealed January 1, 2033.
 15 17    The division takes effect upon enactment and applies to
 15 18 renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from biomass feedstock on
 15 19 or after January 1, 2017.
       LSB 5172HZ (1) 86

 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second

 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.
 13 17    An eligible business that fails to comply with the
 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
 13 32    The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during which
 13 33 the eligible business was issued the tax credit.  However, tax
 13 34 credits shall not be issued by EDA prior to July 1, 2018, or
 13 35 claimed by the taxpayer prior to September 1, 2018. The tax
 14  1 credit may be claimed against the individual income tax and the
 14  2 corporate income tax.  The credit is refundable or may, at the
 14  3 election of the taxpayer, be carried forward for up to one tax
 14  4 year.   The tax credit shall not be transferred to any person.
 14  5    The division provides that the program is subject to EDA's
 14  6 maximum aggregate tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal
 14  7 year in Code section 15.119, and not more than $10 million
 14  8 per fiscal year may be issued by the EDA under the program.
 14  9 In addition, the maximum amount of tax credit that may be
 14 10 issued to an eligible business for the production of renewable
 14 11 chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed $1 million or
 14 12 $500,000, depending on whether the eligible business has been
 14 13 operating in Iowa at the time of application for five or fewer
 14 14 years, or more than five years, respectively.  An eligible
 14 15 business shall not receive more than five tax credits under
 14 16 the program.  The EDA is required to issue tax credits on a
 14 17 first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
 14 18 $10 million per fiscal year is reached.  If the amount of
 14 19 tax credits exceeds this amount in a fiscal year, the EDA
 14 20 is required to establish a wait list and give priority in
 14 21 subsequent years to the eligible businesses on the wait list.
 14 22    The division provides for the confidentiality of certain
 14 23 information under the program.  The identity of a tax credit
 14 24 recipient and the amount of the tax credit shall be considered
 14 25 public information under Code chapter 22 (examination of public
 14 26 records), but any other information or record in the possession
 14 27 of the EDA with respect to the program shall be presumed by
 14 28 the EDA to be a trade secret protected under Code chapter 550
 14 29 or common law and shall be kept confidential by the EDA unless
 14 30 otherwise ordered by a court.
 14 31    The division requires EDA to submit to the general assembly
 14 32 and the governor an annual report describing the activities of
 14 33 the program for each calendar year and including information
 14 34 specified in the division. Information is required to be
 14 35 reported in an aggregate form to protect the presumption
 15  1 of confidentiality and to prevent, as much as possible,
 15  2 information being attributable to any particular eligible
 15  3 business.  The report for the first calendar year the tax
 15  4 credit is available under the program (2017) is due by January
 15  5 31, 2019, and reports covering subsequent calendar years are
 15  6 due by the same date each year thereafter.  Eligible businesses
 15  7 are required, as part of their agreement with EDA, to collect
 15  8 and provide any information reasonably required by EDA in order
 15  9 to fulfill this reporting requirement.
 15 10    The division adds the program to the list of tax expenditures
 15 11 to be reviewed by the legislative tax expenditure committee in
 15 12 calendar year 2022.
 15 13    The tax credit program is repealed July 1, 2030. References
 15 14 to the renewable chemical production tax credit in provisions
 15 15 of the Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax
 15 16 are repealed January 1, 2033.
 15 17    The division takes effect upon enactment and applies to
 15 18 renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from biomass feedstock on
 15 19 or after January 1, 2017.
       LSB 5172HZ (1) 86
       mm/sc
 11 16 production tax credit program enacted in this division of this
 11 17 Act shall not be issued by the economic development authority
 11 18 prior to July 1, 2018, and shall not be claimed by a taxpayer
 11 19 prior to September 1, 2018.
 11 20    Sec. 15.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This division of this
 11 21 Act, being deemed of immediate importance, takes effect upon
 11 22 enactment.
 11 23    Sec. 16.  APPLICABILITY.  This division of this Act applies
 11 24 to renewable chemicals produced in the state from biomass
 11 25 feedstock on or after January 1, 2017.
 11 26                           EXPLANATION
 11 27 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 11 28 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 11 29    This bill relates to the administration of programs by
 11 30 the economic development authority (EDA) by modifying the
 11 31 high quality jobs program and creating a renewable chemical
 11 32 production tax credit program.
 11 33    DIVISION I ==== HIGH QUALITY JOBS PROGRAM.  Division I limits
 11 34 for a period of five or six fiscal years the amount of tax
 11 35 credits that may be allocated to the high quality jobs program,
 12  1 which under current law is subject to EDA's maximum aggregate
 12  2 tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal year in Code section
 12  3 15.119.  The bill provides that for each of the five fiscal
 12  4 years beginning on July 1, 2016, and ending on June 30, 2021,
 12  5 the authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of
 12  6 that $170 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This
 12  7 provision is repealed July 1, 2021.
 12  8    If the aggregate amount of renewable chemical production
 12  9 tax credits awarded by EDA for the fiscal period beginning on
 12 10 July 1, 2018, and ending June 30, 2021, equals or exceeds $27
 12 11 million, then an additional year of high quality jobs program
 12 12 tax credit allocation limitation occurs and for the fiscal
 12 13 year beginning July 1, 2021, and ending June 30, 2022, the
 12 14 authority shall not allocate more than $105 million of its $170
 12 15 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This provision
 12 16 is repealed July 1, 2022.
 12 17    DIVISION II ==== RENEWABLE CHEMICAL PRODUCTION TAX CREDIT.
 12 18   Division II creates a renewable chemical production tax credit
 12 19 program (program) that will be administered by the EDA and that
 12 20 will provide tax credits to eligible businesses that produce
 12 21 renewable chemicals in Iowa from biomass feedstock.  "Renewable
 12 22 chemical", "biomass feedstock", and other related terms are
 12 23 defined in the division.
 12 24    In order to qualify for the tax credit, a business must
 12 25 meet several requirements.  First, the business must be
 12 26 physically located in Iowa and operated for profit under
 12 27 single management.  Second, the business must not be an
 12 28 entity providing professional services, health care services,
 12 29 or medical treatments, or be engaged primarily in retail
 12 30 operations.  Third, the business must have organized, expanded,
 12 31 or located in Iowa on or after the effective date of the
 12 32 division.  Fourth, the business must not be, in the discretion
 12 33 of the EDA, ineligible under certain provisions relating to the
 12 34 relocation or reduction of business operations within Iowa.
 12 35 Fifth, the business must be in compliance with all agreements
 13  1 entered into under the program or other programs administered
 13  2 by the EDA.
 13  3    An eligible business seeking a tax credit is required to
 13  4 submit an application to the EDA containing various information
 13  5 during the calendar year following the calendar year in which
 13  6 the renewable chemicals are produced. The EDA may accept
 13  7 applications on a continuous basis or may establish an annual
 13  8 application deadline.
 13  9    Before being issued a tax credit, an eligible business
 13 10 is required to enter into an agreement with the EDA for the
 13 11 successful completion of all requirements of the program.  The
 13 12 EDA is authorized to impose two compliance cost fees under the
 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second
 13 14 fee equals 0.5 percent of the value of the tax credit claimed
 13 15 pursuant to the agreement if the agreement has an aggregate tax
 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.
 13 17    An eligible business that fails to comply with the
 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
 13 32    The tax credit shall be claimed for the tax year during which
 13 33 the eligible business was issued the tax credit.  However, tax
 13 34 credits shall not be issued by EDA prior to July 1, 2018, or
 13 35 claimed by the taxpayer prior to September 1, 2018. The tax
 14  1 credit may be claimed against the individual income tax and the
 14  2 corporate income tax.  The credit is refundable or may, at the
 14  3 election of the taxpayer, be carried forward for up to one tax
 14  4 year.   The tax credit shall not be transferred to any person.
 14  5    The division provides that the program is subject to EDA's
 14  6 maximum aggregate tax credit cap of $170 million per fiscal
 14  7 year in Code section 15.119, and not more than $10 million
 14  8 per fiscal year may be issued by the EDA under the program.
 14  9 In addition, the maximum amount of tax credit that may be
 14 10 issued to an eligible business for the production of renewable
 14 11 chemicals in a calendar year shall not exceed $1 million or
 14 12 $500,000, depending on whether the eligible business has been
 14 13 operating in Iowa at the time of application for five or fewer
 14 14 years, or more than five years, respectively.  An eligible
 14 15 business shall not receive more than five tax credits under
 14 16 the program.  The EDA is required to issue tax credits on a
 14 17 first=come, first=served basis until the maximum amount of
 14 18 $10 million per fiscal year is reached.  If the amount of
 14 19 tax credits exceeds this amount in a fiscal year, the EDA
 14 20 is required to establish a wait list and give priority in
 14 21 subsequent years to the eligible businesses on the wait list.
 14 22    The division provides for the confidentiality of certain
 14 23 information under the program.  The identity of a tax credit
 14 24 recipient and the amount of the tax credit shall be considered
 14 25 public information under Code chapter 22 (examination of public
 14 26 records), but any other information or record in the possession
 14 27 of the EDA with respect to the program shall be presumed by
 14 28 the EDA to be a trade secret protected under Code chapter 550
 14 29 or common law and shall be kept confidential by the EDA unless
 14 30 otherwise ordered by a court.
 14 31    The division requires EDA to submit to the general assembly
 14 32 and the governor an annual report describing the activities of
 14 33 the program for each calendar year and including information
 14 34 specified in the division. Information is required to be
 14 35 reported in an aggregate form to protect the presumption
 15  1 of confidentiality and to prevent, as much as possible,
 15  2 information being attributable to any particular eligible
 15  3 business.  The report for the first calendar year the tax
 15  4 credit is available under the program (2017) is due by January
 15  5 31, 2019, and reports covering subsequent calendar years are
 15  6 due by the same date each year thereafter.  Eligible businesses
 15  7 are required, as part of their agreement with EDA, to collect
 15  8 and provide any information reasonably required by EDA in order
 15  9 to fulfill this reporting requirement.
 15 10    The division adds the program to the list of tax expenditures
 15 11 to be reviewed by the legislative tax expenditure committee in
 15 12 calendar year 2022.
 15 13    The tax credit program is repealed July 1, 2030. References
 15 14 to the renewable chemical production tax credit in provisions
 15 15 of the Code relating to the individual and corporate income tax
 15 16 are repealed January 1, 2033.
 15 17    The division takes effect upon enactment and applies to
 15 18 renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from biomass feedstock on
 15 19 or after January 1, 2017.
       LSB 5172HZ (1) 86
       mm/sc
 11 17 Act shall not be issued by the economic development authority
 11 18 prior to July 1, 2018, and shall not be claimed by a taxpayer
 11 19 prior to September 1, 2018.
 11 20    Sec. 15.  EFFECTIVE UPON ENACTMENT.  This division of this
 11 21 Act, being deemed of immediate importance, takes effect upon
 11 22 enactment.
 11 23    Sec. 16.  APPLICABILITY.  This division of this Act applies
 11 24 to renewable chemicals produced in the state from biomass
 11 25 feedstock on or after January 1, 2017.
 11 26                           EXPLANATION
 11 27 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 11 28 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 11 29    This bill relates to the administration of programs by
 11 30 the economic development authority (EDA) by modifying the
 11 31 high quality jobs program and creating a renewable chemical
 11 32 production tax credit program.

 12 15 million cap to the high quality jobs program.  This provision
 12 16 is repealed July 1, 2022.

 13  6 the renewable chemicals are produced. The EDA may accept
 13  7 applications on a continuous basis or may establish an annual
 13  8 application deadline.

 13 10 is required to enter into an agreement with the EDA for the
 13 11 successful completion of all requirements of the program.  The
 13 12 EDA is authorized to impose two compliance cost fees under the
 13 13 program.  The first fee equals $500 per agreement.  The second
 13 14 fee equals 0.5 percent of the value of the tax credit claimed
 13 15 pursuant to the agreement if the agreement has an aggregate tax
 13 16 credit value of $100,000 or greater.
 13 17    An eligible business that fails to comply with the
 13 18 requirements of the program or the terms of an agreement with
 13 19 the EDA may have its tax credits reduced, terminated, or
 13 20 rescinded, and may be subject to the repayment or recapture of
 13 21 claimed tax credits.
 13 22    The tax credit equals the product of $.05 multiplied by the
 13 23 number of pounds of renewable chemicals produced in Iowa from
 13 24 biomass feedstock by the eligible business during the calendar
 13 25 year in excess of the eligible business's pre=eligibility
 13 26 production threshold. "Pre=eligibility production threshold"
 13 27 is defined in the bill. Renewable chemicals produced by
 13 28 an eligible business either prior to calendar year 2017 or
 13 29 prior to the date the business first qualifies as an eligible
 13 30 business, or after calendar year 2026, shall not qualify for
 13 31 the tax credit.
